thread.title: Loss to Ottawa ends Armada's playoff hopes
thread.title_full: Loss to Ottawa ends Armada's playoff hopes

author: Clayton Freeman
title: Loss to Ottawa ends Armada's playoff hopes
text:
Loss to Ottawa ends Armada's playoff hopes 
By Clayton Freeman Wed, Oct 21, 2015 @ 10:29 pm Fran Ruchalski for the Times-Union The Armada's Pascal Millien (center) brings the ball up field in the first half against the Ottawa Fury on Wednesday at the Baseball Grounds of Jacksonville. 
It was a night for the Haitian Laser and the Brazilian Pinball. 
The Jacksonville Armada’s short history has never seen a free kick like Mechack Jerome’s 35-yard rocket. 
But a far less stunning free kick from Rafael Alves of the Ottawa Fury ensured the Armada’s season will have an early end. 
Jerome stunned the crowd with a long-range free kick, but North American Soccer League fall champion Ottawa struck back in the second half to defeat the Armada 3-1 at the Baseball Grounds on Wednesday. 
Alves turned Jacksonville’s night upside down by scoring the tying goal in the 59th minute. 
“We found ourselves up, and instead of embracing it, I felt we kind of got away from what we were doing well in the first half,” Armada interim coach Eric Dade said. 
Alves and Sinisa Ubiparipovic scored in a four-minute span for Ottawa, a one-two punch that quashed the Armada’s hopes of reaching the NASL playoffs in the franchise’s debut season. 
“We’ve been struggling with that all season,” forward Pascal Millien said. “The first 10 minutes of the second half are always killing us.” 
This time, it was fatal. 
The Fury (13-1-5) planned to use its rugged physique to overwhelm the smaller Armada squad in the box on set plays — and nearly succeeded early. 
Ottawa’s Colin Falvey headed a shot off the crossbar, Mauro Eustaquio had a goal wiped out for offside and Ryan Richter forced Armada keeper Miguel Gallardo into a clearing punch of a point-blank shot. 
The Armada (5-10-3) came close after 15 minutes, as Akeil Barrett’s 40-yard run rounded Ottawa goalkeeper Romuald Peiser but couldn’t beat a trio of defenders who scrambled back to guard the empty net. 
But Jacksonville spent much of the half clearing Ottawa’s set plays, until Fury midfielder Julian de Guzman sent Millien head over heels with a sliding tackle seven minutes from halftime. 
Up stepped Jerome for the ensuing free kick, some 35 yards from the net. 
“I had been working on that in training,” he said. “Finally, I got it tonight.” 
The Haitian defender’s shot first headed left before veering right with tremendous speed and sailing past a bewildered Peiser in the Ottawa goal. 
But with the Armada on the verge of a win that would sustain its postseason chances, it all fell apart. Brazilian defender Alves drove a 20-yard free kick that ricocheted off several legs and skidded past Gallardo. It wasn’t as dramatic as Jerome’s effort, but it counted just the same. 
Moments later, Ubiparipovic took possession just inside the Armada box and lofted a smooth chip that floated over Gallardo and dipped under the bar. 
Ottawa’s Andrew Wiedeman scored in stoppage time to cap the night and clinch the fall championship, as Fury players carried coach Marc Dos Santos aloft in celebration. 
The Armada heads to FC Edmonton on Sunday, the club’s last chance to prevent a winless road season in its debut. 
“There’ll be a lot of pride in us going on the road, trying to find a result,” Dade said.
